questions.question_text: What is environmental pollution?

options.label: A
options.text: The addition of nutrients to the environment that benefit life forms.

options.label: B
options.text: The effect of undesirable changes in our surroundings that have harmful effects on plants, animals and human beings.

options.label: C
options.text: The natural process of recycling elements like carbon and nitrogen.

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in temperature of the earth's atmosphere due to human activity.

questions.key_concept: Definition of environmental pollution.

questions.question_text: A substance that contaminates and degrades the earth's environment, having an adverse impact on life forms, is called a:

options.label: A
options.text: Catalyst

options.label: B
options.text: Nutrient

options.label: C
options.text: Pollutant

options.label: D
options.text: Scavenger

questions.key_concept: Definition of a pollutant.

questions.question_text: Based on their origin, pollutants are classified into two types. What are they?

options.label: A
options.text: Organic and Inorganic

options.label: B
options.text: Primary and Secondary

options.label: C
options.text: Natural and Man-made

options.label: D
options.text: Biodegradable and Non-biodegradable

questions.key_concept: Classification of pollutants by origin.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a natural source of air pollutants?

options.label: A
options.text: Volcanic eruptions releasing sulphur dioxide.

options.label: B
options.text: Decaying vegetation releasing nitrous oxide.

options.label: C
options.text: Factories releasing carbon monoxide.

options.label: D
options.text: Forest fires releasing carbon monoxide.

questions.key_concept: Identifying man-made vs. natural sources of pollution.

questions.question_text: How does the role of pollutants added naturally differ from those added by human activities, regarding the environment's capacity to handle them?

options.label: A
options.text: Nature can accommodate pollutants from both sources at the same fast rate indefinitely.

options.label: B
options.text: Nature can accommodate natural pollutants but not man-made ones under any condition.

options.label: C
options.text: Nature can recycle or store pollutants in harmless form, but when added faster than this rate (often by human activity), it leads to environmental deterioration.

options.label: D
options.text: Man-made pollutants are always harmless, while natural pollutants are always toxic.

questions.key_concept: Comparison of environmental impact based on the rate of pollutant addition.

questions.question_text: Why is 'air pollution' specifically defined as a degradation of air quality?

options.label: A
options.text: Because air always has a fixed, pure composition that never changes.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the concentration of harmful contaminants alters the composition of ordinary air, adversely affecting life.

options.label: C
options.text: Because pollution only occurs when the oxygen level drops to zero.

options.label: D
options.text: Because air pollution is only caused by gases and not by particulate matter.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the definition of air pollution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a gaseous air pollutant?

options.label: A
options.text: Dust

options.label: B
options.text: Smoke

options.label: C
options.text: Sulphur dioxide

options.label: D
options.text: Sand

questions.key_concept: Identifying a gaseous pollutant.

questions.question_text: The poisonous gas that prevents haemoglobin from carrying oxygen to body tissues is:

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: Sulphur dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon monoxide

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrogen dioxide

questions.key_concept: Identifying the pollutant that binds with haemoglobin.

questions.question_text: Which pollutant is primarily responsible for causing lung cancer and is NOT generally a product of fuel combustion in vehicles?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon monoxide

options.label: B
options.text: Tobacco smoke

options.label: C
options.text: Sulphur dioxide

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrogen oxides

questions.key_concept: Common trap: Associating all lung cancer with vehicular exhaust, ignoring tobacco.

questions.question_text: A dark, thick fog laden with dust and soot, formed from a combination of nitrogen oxides, sulphur oxides, and partially oxidized hydrocarbons, is known as:

options.label: A
options.text: Mist

options.label: B
options.text: Smog

options.label: C
options.text: Dew

options.label: D
options.text: Fume

questions.key_concept: Application: Identifying smog from its description.

questions.question_text: Compare the primary sources of Carbon Monoxide (CO) and Lead in the air. Which statement is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Both CO and Lead primarily come from the decay of crop residues.

options.label: B
options.text: CO comes from incomplete combustion of fuels, while Lead comes from motor vehicles using tetraethyl lead.

options.label: C
options.text: CO is a natural pollutant from volcanoes, while Lead is purely industrial.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are emitted in equal quantities from fertilizer industries.

questions.key_concept: Comparing the distinct sources of different gaseous/particulate pollutants.

questions.question_text: Why is carbon monoxide considered particularly dangerous even at low concentrations?

options.label: A
options.text: It is denser than air and settles in lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: It has a strong smell that causes immediate nausea.

options.label: C
options.text: It binds with haemoglobin over 200 times more strongly than oxygen, drastically reducing blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

options.label: D
options.text: It converts directly into solid carbon in the bloodstream.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the high toxicity of carbon monoxide.

concepts.concept_name: Acid Rain: Composition, Cause, and Impact

questions.question_text: What is acid rain?

options.label: A
options.text: Rainwater with a pH greater than 7.

options.label: B
options.text: Any precipitation (rain, snow, fog) that is more acidic than normal water.

options.label: C
options.text: Rainwater contaminated only with nitric acid.

options.label: D
options.text: Rain that falls only in industrial areas.

questions.key_concept: Definition of acid rain.

questions.question_text: Normal rainwater is slightly acidic mainly due to the presence of:

options.label: A
options.text: Sulphuric acid

options.label: B
options.text: Nitric acid

options.label: C
options.text: Carbonic acid from dissolved CO2

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrochloric acid

questions.key_concept: Identifying the cause of normal rainwater acidity.

questions.question_text: Acid rain with a pH as low as 2 is primarily caused by:

options.label: A
options.text: Dissolved carbon dioxide alone.

options.label: B
options.text: Oxides of nitrogen and sulphur dissolving in rainwater to form strong mineral acids.

options.label: C
options.text: High concentrations of oxygen in the atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: The evaporation of sea water.

questions.key_concept: Trap: Confusing normal weak acidity with strong acidity from pollution.

questions.question_text: Which chemical reaction correctly represents the formation of a major component of acid rain?

options.label: A
options.text: 2NO2 + H2O -> HNO2 + HNO3

options.label: B
options.text: CO2 + H2O -> CH4 + O2

options.label: C
options.text: N2 + O2 -> NO2

options.label: D
options.text: S + H2O -> H2SO4

questions.key_concept: Application: Identifying the correct chemical equation for acid rain formation.

questions.question_text: How does the impact of acid rain on soil differ from its impact on marble structures?

options.label: A
options.text: It adds nutrients to soil but strengthens marble.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes soil more fertile and cleans marble surfaces.

options.label: C
options.text: It removes basic nutrients (like calcium) from soil, reducing fertility, and reacts with calcium carbonate in marble to weaken it.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on soil but discolors marble.

questions.key_concept: Comparing two distinct damaging effects of acid rain.

questions.question_text: Why is using a scrubber an effective method to reduce acid rain?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the combustion temperature, preventing acid formation.

options.label: B
options.text: It absorbs gaseous pollutants like sulphur dioxide from industrial emissions before they enter the atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: It neutralizes acid rain after it has fallen on the ground.

options.label: D
options.text: It converts nitric acid in the air back into nitrogen and oxygen.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind a control method for acid rain.

questions.question_text: What is the greenhouse effect?

options.label: A
options.text: The trapping of solar heat by gases like CO2 and water vapour in the atmosphere, warming the Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: The process of growing plants in glass houses in cold regions.

options.label: C
options.text: The depletion of the ozone layer by CFCs.

options.label: D
options.text: The formation of smog in industrial cities.

questions.key_concept: Definition of the greenhouse effect.

questions.question_text: Which gas makes the largest relative contribution to the greenhouse effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Methane (CH4)

options.label: B
options.text: Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrous Oxide (N2O)

questions.key_concept: Identifying the primary greenhouse gas.

questions.question_text: What is the relationship between the greenhouse effect and global warming?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the same phenomenon.

options.label: B
options.text: Global warming is the harmful rise in Earth's average temperature caused by an enhanced greenhouse effect due to increased greenhouse gases.

options.label: C
options.text: Global warming causes the greenhouse effect.

options.label: D
options.text: The greenhouse effect is a myth, but global warming is real.

questions.key_concept: Trap: Confusing the natural effect with the harmful consequence.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a predicted consequence of global warming?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in sea levels due to increased evaporation.

options.label: B
options.text: Flooding of coastal areas due to melting glaciers and polar ice caps.

options.label: C
options.text: More stable and predictable rainfall patterns worldwide.

options.label: D
options.text: A significant global cooling trend by 2050.

questions.key_concept: Application: Identifying an effect of global warming.

questions.question_text: Compare the primary sources of Carbon Dioxide (CO2) and Methane (CH4) as greenhouse gases.

options.label: A
options.text: Both are primarily released from the incomplete combustion of gasoline in cars.

options.label: B
options.text: CO2 primarily comes from burning fossil fuels and respiration, while CH4 comes from anaerobic decay of organic matter and incomplete combustion.

options.label: C
options.text: CO2 is a natural gas only from volcanoes, while CH4 is only man-made from industries.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are primarily emitted from refrigerators and air conditioners.

questions.key_concept: Comparing sources of different greenhouse gases.

questions.question_text: Why is planting more trees suggested as a way to reduce global warming?

options.label: A
options.text: Trees block sunlight from reaching the Earth, causing cooling.

options.label: B
options.text: Trees absorb carbon dioxide (a greenhouse gas) during photosynthesis, reducing its atmospheric concentration.

options.label: C
options.text: Trees release large amounts of oxygen which dilutes other greenhouse gases.

options.label: D
options.text: Trees increase the albedo (reflectivity) of the Earth, deflecting heat.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind a method to combat global warming.

questions.question_text: Ozone is a gas found in which layer of the atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: Troposphere (near Earth's surface)

options.label: B
options.text: Stratosphere (upper layer)

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrosphere

options.label: D
options.text: Lithosphere

questions.key_concept: Definition/Location of the ozone layer.

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of the ozone layer in the atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: To trap heat and keep the Earth warm.

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb harmful ultraviolet (UV) rays from the sun.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide oxygen for breathing.

options.label: D
options.text: To cause acid rain.

questions.key_concept: Identifying the protective function of ozone.

questions.question_text: The formation of ozone in the stratosphere involves which process?

options.label: A
options.text: Burning of fossil fuels.

options.label: B
options.text: Action of ultraviolet rays on oxygen molecules (O2).

options.label: C
options.text: Combustion in automobile engines.

options.label: D
options.text: Decay of organic matter.

questions.key_concept: Trap: Confusing ozone formation with ozone destruction processes.

questions.question_text: A hole in the ozone layer was first detected above which region?

options.label: A
options.text: The Arctic

options.label: B
options.text: Antarctica

options.label: C
options.text: The Himalayas

options.label: D
options.text: The Sahara Desert

questions.key_concept: Application: Recalling a key fact about ozone depletion.

questions.question_text: How do Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and Oxides of Nitrogen contribute to ozone depletion differently?

options.label: A
options.text: CFCs directly produce ozone, while NOx absorbs it.

options.label: B
options.text: Both are harmless gases that have no effect on ozone.

options.label: C
options.text: CFCs release chlorine radicals that destroy ozone in a chain reaction, while NO from aircraft fuels reacts directly with ozone.

options.label: D
options.text: CFCs are the main cause of acid rain, while NOx depletes ozone.

questions.key_concept: Comparing the mechanisms of two major ozone-depleting agents.

questions.question_text: Why is the depletion of the ozone layer a serious concern?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to increased levels of carbon dioxide, causing global warming.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows more harmful ultraviolet radiation to reach Earth, increasing risks like skin cancer and damage to organisms.

options.label: C
options.text: It causes the greenhouse effect to cease, leading to an ice age.

options.label: D
options.text: It results in the formation of more ozone at ground level, which is beneficial.

questions.key_concept: Reasoning behind the dangers of ozone depletion.
